I'm all for leveling the playing field in terms of opportunity and quality of education. But I'm not for giving Obama's children a built in advantage over the children of an uneducated white laborer, just because they happen to be non-white.

No doubt that affirmative action does cause racism to occur today. On an individual basis -- merit for merit comparisons -- white individuals do get a lesser chance compared to those who are not white. It is amazing how many intelligent people just really don't want to hear this truth.

No doubt also that in the past blacks were discriminated against to levels which we cannot imagine. They couldn't live in FHA houses. Men were incarcerated and still are at extremely high levels. They were charged and imprisoned when the whites could no longer force them to be slaves. They had to write essay tests on state constitutions in order to vote.

In any case, I really don't see how discriminating on a merit for merit basis today ends racism. As long as you are choosing one person over another for his race, you practice racism towards the other person... and they generally don't forget it.

I just see racism now take a new form and context. If we want to stop racism, we want to stop racism, we want to stop looking at people at all in terms of race. Someday we will get there. Someday.

While not in the top 10% of  her school, Ms. Fisher may still be in the top 10% or even top 5% of the overall applicant pool. That, is the unfairness of it all. She is being punished for going to a better school to get a better K-12 education. America needs to stop punishing the hardworking and successful. Treat everyone as an individual, regardless of the color of their skin. Colleges should not be allowed to ask for a student's race just like employers are not allowed to, especially now with so many Americans being mixed race. We are all part of the American race. Period.

So Fisher's complaint is that UT cannot have an affirmative action scholarship in addition to a colorblind scholarship? This is nonsense.

The Top 10% scholarship is great; ironically, it's even progressive since schools are so racially homogenous. Fisher missed out on the colorblind scholarship because (frankly) she wasn't smart enough.

The second tier of scholarship has an affirmative action component. You can be annoyed that the school includes race in this decision, but to complain that it is a different scholarship than the first decision (which she absolutely objectively did not qualify for) is hash.

There are scholarships for females studying science and scholarships for first-generation college students and scholarships for kids who aren't brilliant but can catch a football. The diversity of types of scholarships adds diversity to our college campuses; it's one of the most important types of diversity at play in education.

It is shown there that the overall girl:boy ratio resides between the maximal and minimal girl:boy birth ratios. I also surmised there that the maximal and minimal constituent girl:boy ratios could be approached arbitrarily close. It is nice to see your simulation evidence supports this claim. However, to actually "confirm" the claim in general is another matter, albeit hopefully accomplishable without too great an effort.

The girl:boy ratio for arbitrary number of consecutive boys stopping rule can be deduced analytically, just as in the case of 2 consecutive boys. I will perhaps write out the formula in a later post.

Expanding slightly on your last paragraph, in general, if the stopping rule does not impose dependency, the sequence can be decomposed into copies of the constituent independent sequences.

While I am no longer doing this for a living (there is a new Dr. Salary), the only job on this list that likely suffers from a selection bias (people who complete the PayScale survey are not typical of people doing the job) are fast food workers.

I worked fast food, and it is very clear what the pay level is: minimum wage plus a bit. The fast food workers who go to PayScale are likely atypical. My guess is they are more educated, were downsized into this job, and so more bitter.

Many fast food workers probably do think they are aiding obesity (a serious health problem), and so have a negative few of their contribution to society. It likely just isn't as high as 43%.

As for the rest of the jobs, the sampling here is much more uniform, since workers in these occupations would benefit from learning what their job pays at PayScale. Hence a broad cross-section go to PayScale.

By the way, this is not what PayScale thinks about these jobs, this is the percentage of workers in these jobs who think the value is to society is low. Any percentage above 1% is above average - the typical job has less than 1% giving this very negative answer.

That a small but significant fraction of workers in industries that, e.g., aid addictions (gambling, tobacco, alcohol) see their jobs in a negative light gives me hope for humanity.

A Toxicologist

From the standpoint of a person of few means, it's obvious our economy is not based on concern for anything but profit. There is a huge concentration of wealth in the top 1% of the population, and those big companies are certainly not owned by anyone at my income level. Nor can anyone at my income level afford any shares of such companies. Nor would I have enough money to make purchases of such shares profitable.

And when it comes to needing those medications, if it weren't for the fact that the money was coming from somewhere other than my own pocket, my child would likely be dead right now. And this is the biggest part of what I'm talking about. There are people who profit tremendously from these companies. And our lives come second to their wants. And that is unacceptable regardless of the reasoning. Our economy forces these conditions. We have to change the way we relate to each other or it will only get worse.
